questions.text: Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for diagnosis of which of the following condition? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toxoplasmosis

 

Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis.

 

It is based on the principle that the presence of anti-toxoplasma antibodies in the patient's serum inhibits the staining of trophozoites by alkaline methylene blue dye.

 

Toxoplasma trophozoites and complement are added to the patient's serum which is then incubated for an hour at 37°C. After incubation, methylene blue dye is added.

 

If anti-toxoplasma antibodies are present in the serum, these are activated by complement and the parasite membrane is lysed. Thus, the trophozoites are not stained (positive result).

 

If there are no antibodies, trophozoites will take up the stain and appear blue under the microscope. This is considered to be a negative result.

 

The dilution of the test serum at which 50% of the tachyoites are not stained is reported as the antibody titer of the test serum. The test is highly sensitive and specific.

 

It cannot differentiate between recent or past infections as it detects only IgG antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paragonimiasis: Incorrect, as the Sabin-Feldman dye test is not used for diagnosing Paragonimiasis.

 

Option B. Hydatid cyst: Incorrect, the diagnosis of hydatid disease is primarily performed using imaging techniques and the Casoni skin test.

 

Option D. Cryptococcus: Incorrect, Cryptococcus infections are typically diagnosed using fungal cultures and cryptococcal antigen tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Sabin-Feldman dye test remains a gold standard for the serological diagnosis of Toxoplasmosis due to its ability to detect the presence of specific antibodies against Toxoplasma gondii, reflecting the body's immune response to the infection.

 

Additional Information

 

Skin test for diagnosis of parasitic infections:

 

  1. Casoni test – Hydatid disease
  2. Montenegro test – Kala azar
  3. Frenkel test – Toxoplasmosis
  4. Fairley test – Schistosomiasis
  5. Bachman test – Trichinellosis

questions.text: Which of the following is characteristic feature of hemolysis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased haptoglobin

 

Characteristic feature of hemolysis is decreased haptoglobin. Serum haptoglobin levels are decreased in hemolytic anemias.

 

There are two Types of hemolysis with following features -  

 

  • Intravascular hemolysis - hemolysis that occurs mainly within the blood vessels

 

Features:

  • Decreased haptoglobin
  • Increased lactate dehydrogenase
  • Hemoglobinuria
  • Methemoglobinemia
  • Extravascular hemolysis - hemolysis that occurs in spleen, liver, bone marrow, and lymph nodes

 

Features:

  • Splenomegaly
  • Jaundice
  • Variable decreases in plasma haptoglobin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reticulocytopenia: Hemolysis typically causes reticulocytosis, not reticulocytopenia.

 

Option C. Neutropenia: Hemolysis affects red blood cells, not neutrophils.

 

Option D. Increased conjugated bilirubin: Hemolysis usually increases unconjugated bilirubin due to the breakdown of red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased haptoglobin is a characteristic feature of hemolysis, distinguishing it from other conditions.

questions.text: Match the following cells with their locations: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-b, 2-a, 3-c, 4-d  

 

The correct matches for the cells and their respective locations are as follows:

 

  1. Kupffer cells (b) Liver: Kupffer cells are specialized macrophages located in the liver, involved in the breakdown of red blood cells and the immune response within the liver.
  2. Parietal cells (a) Stomach: Parietal cells are found in the lining of the stomach and are responsible for secreting hydrochloric acid (HCl), which aids in digestion.
  3. Dust cells (c) Alveoli: Dust cells, also known as alveolar macrophages, are found in the alveoli of the lungs. They play a crucial role in removing inhaled particles and pathogens from the alveolar spaces.
  4. Clara cells (d) Bronchioles: Clara cells, now more commonly referred to as club cells, are found in the bronchioles of the lungs. They secrete surfactant proteins and detoxify harmful substances inhaled into the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What treatment should be avoided for a male patient in his mid-40s who was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident, and presents with a heart rate of 120/min, respiratory rate of 30/min, and an X-ray image of his chest? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chest tube insertion

 

Given Scenario with x ray shows left sided traumatic diaphragmatic rupture with herniation of stomach. Nasogastric tube insertion, log roll, or epidural anesthesia can be done. However, intercostal drain should not be put as it would traumatic the herniated content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The provided image displays an elevated left hemidiaphragm with stomach herniated into thorax, likely due to a diaphragmatic hernia resulting from blunt trauma in a road traffic accident.

 

  • Chest tube insertion or thoracostomy is not recommended in cases of diaphragmatic hernia and is contraindicated
  • Chest tube insertion is generally indicated for pneumothorax, hemothorax, chylothorax, pleural effusion, among others, but is contraindicated in the presence of pulmonary adhesions, pulmonary trauma, coagulopathy, and diaphragmatic hernia.
  • To insert a chest tube, the 5th intercostal space should be accessed anterior to the midaxillary line, within the triangle of safety, which is located above the level of the nipple and below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.
  • Acquired diaphragmatic hernia does not contraindicate nasogastric tube insertion, log roll, or epidural anesthesia.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used to prevent painful vaso-occlusive crises and decrease long-term complications in sickle cell anemia? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydroxyurea.

 

Hydroxyurea is widely used in the management of sickle cell anemia. It helps to increase the concentration of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) in the bloodstream, which is less likely to participate in the sickling process that characterizes sickle cell disease. By reducing the sickling of red blood cells, hydroxyurea lowers the incidence of vaso-occlusive crises that cause pain and can lead to organ damage. Additionally, the drug has been shown to have a positive impact on the long-term complications associated with sickle cell anemia, including reducing the risk of stroke and other serious events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methotrexate plus leucovorin: This combination is not used for sickle cell anemia. Methotrexate is primarily used in the treatment of certain cancers and autoimmune diseases, and leucovorin is given to mitigate the side effects of methotrexate.

 

Option C. Methionine: Methionine is an essential amino acid that is not used to treat sickle cell anemia or its complications. It has no role in preventing vaso-occlusive crises. Rather L-glutamine is the amino acid that is used in sickle cell disease.

 

Option D. Eltrombopag: Eltrombopag is a medication that stimulates platelet production and is used in conditions like chronic immune thrombocytopenia. It is not indicated for the treatment or prevention of complications in sickle cell anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydroxyurea is the primary medication used to prevent painful vaso-occlusive crises and decrease long-term complications in sickle cell anemia by increasing the concentration of fetal hemoglobin (HbF).

questions.text: Mention the type of joint present at the marked area: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Saddle

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the hand, with the arrow pointing to the first carpometacarpal joint, which is the joint between the carpal bone (trapezium) and the first metacarpal bone (base of the thumb). This joint is a classical example of a saddle joint.

 

In a saddle joint, one bone has a concave and convex surface that articulates with the complementary convex and concave surface of the other bone, resembling a saddle shape. The joint is surrounded by a capsule and filled with synovial fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ellipsoid: An ellipsoid joint has an oval-shaped articular surface that fits into an elliptical cavity, allowing for biaxial movement. This type of joint is not present at the marked area.

 

Option B. Condylar: A condylar joint has an oval projection of one bone fitting into an elliptical cavity of another bone, allowing for biaxial movement. This type of joint is not present at the marked area.

 

Option C. Plane: A plane joint has two flat or slightly curved articular surfaces that allow for gliding or sliding movements. This type of joint is not present at the marked area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first carpometacarpal joint at the base of the thumb is a saddle joint, allowing a wide range of thumb movements.

Saddle Joint – Mnemonic – PICS

Concavo-convex surface in each bone

P – Patellofemoral joint

I – incudomalleolar joint

C – Carpometacarpal joint

S – Sternoclavicular joint

choices.text: Parkinson Disease
Alzheimer's disease

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is most commonly associated with Down's syndrome: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alzheimer’s disease

 

Individuals with Down’s syndrome are at a significantly higher risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease, often in their 30s and 40s, due to the presence of three copies of chromosome 21, which contains the APP gene involved in the production of amyloid precursor protein—a key factor in Alzheimer’s pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parkinson Disease: Not specifically associated with Down's syndrome.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia: No significant correlation between Down's syndrome and schizophrenia.

 

Option D. Huntington's Disease: No direct association with Down's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conditions most commonly associated with Down's syndrome:

 

  • Congenital heart disease (in about 35% of cases)
  • Gastrointestinal anomalies (in about 10%)
  • Chronic serous otitis media (in >50%)
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Alzheimer's disease (in the 30's and 40's)
  • Epilepsy (in about 10%)
  • Ocular disorders
  • Reduced fertility
  • Reduced life span (Often due to complications like infections)

questions.text: During the assessment of the breathing component of a trauma patient, which of the following is the most life-threatening injury that should be identified and managed immediately? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tension pneumothorax

 

Injuries that significantly impair ventilation in the short term, such as tension pneumothorax, must be identified during the primary survey and treated immediately.

 

It is important to note that the ABCDE protocol of trauma care should be followed, with the primary survey focusing on identifying and managing life-threatening injuries, followed by the secondary survey to identify all other injuries

 

Tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and compresses the lung, causing it to collapse. This can lead to a rapid buildup of pressure in the chest cavity, compressing the heart and great vessels, which can be life-threatening. It is crucial to identify and manage tension pneumothorax promptly by performing a needle decompression to release the trapped air.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical spine injury: While cervical spine injuries can be serious and require prompt attention, they are not primarily related to the respiratory system. They can result in neurological deficits but are not immediately life-threatening in terms of breathing.

 

Option C. Blunt cardiac injury: Blunt cardiac injury can result from chest trauma and may affect the heart's function. While it can be serious, it may not immediately impact the patient's ability to breathe. However, it requires evaluation and management.

 

Option D. Flail chest: Flail chest is no longer considered an immediate threat to life as per ATLS 2018 guidelines.

questions.text: During a global health conference, you're in a discussion with fellow epidemiologists about the changing patterns of disease occurrence over the years. The conversation shifts towards the steady rise in non-communicable diseases over a considerable time span. One of your colleagues quizzes the group on the terminology for such a trend. Which term best describes this pattern of increasing prevalence over extended periods? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Secular 

 

  • This kind of pattern can be explained by secular trend.
  • Secular Trends (Long Term Fluctuations): Implies changes in occurrence of a disease (progressive increase or decrease) over a long period of time, generally several years or decades.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seasonal: Seasonal trends (Periodic fluctuations) is seasonal variation/fluctuation in occurrence of a disease. Examples: Measles (early spring), upper respiratory infection (winters), gastrointestinal infection (summer).

 

Option B. Cyclical: Cyclic trend (Periodic fluctuations) is occurrence of a disease in cycles spread over short periods of time, which may be days, weeks, months or years. Examples: Measles (every 2-3 years), Rubella (every 6-9 years), Influenza pandemics (every 10-15 years).

 

Option C. Periodic: Periodic fluctuations include both Seasonal and cyclical trends.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secular trends describe long-term changes in disease occurrence over years or decades, distinct from seasonal or cyclical variations.

questions.text: When considering a patient with lung cancer, the imaging studies have measured the tumor size at 2.5 cm. According to the TMN staging system, which stage would be appropriate for this patient? ( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T1c

 

T1c: Correct. T1c is for tumors > 2 to ≤ 3 cm in size, which matches the patient's tumor size of 2.5 cm.

 

According to TNM staging, a patient with lung carcinoma of size 2.5cm is staged as T1c.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T2b: Incorrect. T2b is used for tumors > 4 to ≤ 5 cm in size.

 

Option C. T2a: Incorrect. T2a is for tumors > 3 to ≤ 4 cm in size.

 

Option D. T1a: Incorrect. T1a is for tumors < 1 cm in size.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The TNM staging system for lung cancer uses tumor size and extent (T), lymph node involvement (N), and metastasis (M) to classify the disease. A tumor measuring 2.5 cm is classified as T1c according to the TNM 8th edition criteria.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about triage? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yellow: urgent care needed

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red: ambulatory - This is incorrect because red is used for conditions requiring immediate attention, not for ambulatory patients.

 

Option C. Black: minor injuries - This is incorrect because black is used for patients who are moribund or dead, not for minor injuries.

 

Option D. Green: immediate life threatening - This is incorrect because green is used for ambulatory patients with minor injuries, not for life-threatening conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yellow in triage signifies that urgent care is needed, such as for open fractures or degloving injuries.

questions.text: A farmer is spraying an odourless chemical in the fields, which is an Inhibitor of Complex III of ETC. Identify the compound: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antimycin A

 

Antimycin A is an inhibitor of Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) of the ETC. It binds to the Qo site of cytochrome b and blocks electron transfer from ubiquinol to cytochrome c1, disrupting ATP synthesis. It's used in fisheries and can be employed in agricultural settings for pest control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carboxin: Carboxin is a fungicide, but it primarily inhibits succinate dehydrogenase (Complex II) in the ETC, not Complex III. It interferes with fungal respiration by inhibiting electron transport at this specific complex.

 

Option B. Rotenone: Rotenone is an insecticide and piscicide that inhibits Complex I (NADH dehydrogenase) of the ETC. It acts by blocking electron transport, leading to the cessation of ATP production in the cells it affects.

 

Option C. Cyanide: Cyanide is a potent and highly toxic compound that inhibits Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) of the ETC. It binds to the iron in the heme group of cytochrome c oxidase, stopping cellular respiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibitors of ETC:

 

Complex I- Rotenone, Phenobarbitone, Amobarbital

 

Complex II- Malonate (3C), Carboxin

 

Complex III- Phenformin, Antimycin A, BAL

 

Complex IV- CN, CO, Sodium azide, H2S

 

Pesticides used in agricultural fields:

 

  • Rotenone is also an insecticide, pesticide and a herbicide
  • Carboxin is a fungicide that is commonly used in agricultural practices
  • Antimycin – used in agriculture to control certain pests that affect crops
  • Cyanide

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 127

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was operated for a tumour in the lower end of femur. The gross specimen of the resected tumour is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INCET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The matrix forming the tumor is the cause of calcification.
  • It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone behind multiple myeloma.
  • The classic form of osteosarcoma is typically seen in patients in their second or third decade, with a peak in the adolescent growth spurt.
  • It occurs more frequently in males than in females and is found in the metaphyseal areas of long bones, with 50% of lesions about the knee joint.
  • The distal femur is the most common site, followed by the proximal tibia and then the proximal humerus.
  • Characteristic histological feature is malignant cells with osteoid formation. This osteoid matrix presents as calcification.
  • Osteosarcoma is the most common radiation-induced sarcoma.
  • Clinical features:
    • Almost all patients report progressive pain. Night pain may be an important clue to the true diagnosis, seen in 25% of patients
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Permeated lytic destruction of metaphyseal bone, with eventual cortical breakthrough into the subperiosteal space and subsequent formation of a Codman triangle at the diaphyseal end of the tumor.

 

 

Codman’s triangle

 

  • As the tumor continues to push its way into the extracortical soft tissue, a typical sunburst pattern of neoplastic bone may be seen outside the involved bone.

 

 

  • MRI is the best test to measure the extent of the tumor within the bone and in the soft tissue and to determine the relationship of the tumor to nearby anatomical structures.
  • A bone scan should be obtained to look for skeletal metastases, and radiographs and CT scans of the chest should be done to search for pulmonary metastases; the lungs are the most common sites of metastases.
  • CT scan may be helpful in differentiating osteosarcoma from myositis ossificans or an osteochondroma. The ossification in myositis ossificans is more mature at the periphery of the lesion, whereas the center of osteosarcoma is more heavily ossified.
  • Treatment:
    • It is highly radio-resistant tumor and ideally, treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.
    • With the combination of chemotherapy and surgical treatment, the prognosis for 5-year survival is 70-80%.
    • The drugs commonly used today include high-dose methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and ifosfamide.
    • In osteosarcoma of the extremities, limb-sparing surgery with wide resection of the tumor is the standard approach.
    • Amputation is reserved for the exceptional or recurrent case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chondrosarcoma. It occurs over a broad age range, with peaks between 40 and 60 years for primary chondrosarcoma and between 25 and 45 years for secondary chondrosarcoma. Most common in Proximal location like pelvis (most common site), proximal femur, and proximal humerus. Most common malignant tumor of bone in hand (although rarely occur). Secondary chondrosarcomas arise at the site of a pre-existing benign cartilage lesion like in case of multiple enchondromas and multiple hereditary exostoses. Chondrosarcoma can produce hyperglycemia in 85% cases. Metastasis from Chondrosarcoma most commonly goes to lungs (hematogenous). The radiographic appearance is similar to enchondroma, it is a lesion arising in the medullary cavity with irregular matrix calcification. The pattern of Calcification is described as “Punctate”, “popcorn”, or “comma-shaped”. It has a more aggressive appearance with Bone destruction, cortical erosions, periosteal reaction, and rarely a soft-tissue mass. Treatment is by Wide local excision/Radical excision.

 

 

Option C. GCT. They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance. The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation. Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT. Radiographic findings often are diagnostic. The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone with soap bubble appearance. Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of many multinucleated giant cells (typically 40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells). Curettage and stripping of the cavity is the treatment of choice.

 

 

Option D. Chondroblastoma. Chondroblastoma is a rare type of benign tumor that grows at the ends of the long bones, close to the joints. Most often, the tumors develop at the ends of the femur, tibia, or humerus. They typically occur in children and young adults, and are more common in males. Although chondroblastomas are not cancerous, they can continue to grow if left untreated. A growing tumor can destroy the surrounding bone, making it painful to move the nearby joint. The cause of chondroblastomas is not known. The tumors are thought to arise from the growth plates at the ends of the bones, near joints. Classic “chicken wire” calcification is seen. Epiphysis + calcification + upper end humerus = Chondroblastoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows a cut section of osteosarcoma of the femur.
  • The destructive tumor arises from the metaphysis, with extensive involvement of the marrow cavity and extension into soft tissue.

questions.text: A child developed multiple skin eruptions/burns after exposure to sunlight. Which of the following is the likely defect present in her? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nucleotide excision repair gene defect

 

The clinical scenario described is characteristic of xeroderma pigmentosum, a genetic disorder caused by a defect in the nucleotide excision repair (NER) pathway.

 

This pathway is responsible for repairing DNA damage caused by ultraviolet (UV) radiation from sunlight.

 

In xeroderma pigmentosum, the failure to repair UV-induced DNA damage leads to severe skin sensitivity, hyperpigmentation, multiple skin eruptions, and a significantly increased risk of developing skin cancers such as squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma, and melanoma.

 

In this case:

 

  • The history of skin eruptions and burns after sun exposure is classic for xeroderma pigmentosum.
  • NER gene defects prevent the proper repair of DNA damage caused by UV light, leading to the symptoms observed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mismatch repair gene defect: This defect is associated with Lynch syndrome and other cancers but is not typically related to sunlight-induced skin conditions.

 

Option C. Base excision repair gene defect: This pathway repairs small, non-helix-distorting base lesions in DNA but does not handle UV-induced damage specifically.

 

Option D. Recombination repair gene defect: Recombination repair is involved in repairing double-strand breaks and does not directly relate to UV light-induced damage seen in conditions like xeroderma pigmentosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xeroderma pigmentosum is caused by a defect in the nucleotide excision repair gene, leading to severe sensitivity to UV light, skin eruptions, and an increased risk of skin cancers

choices.text: Decreased GFR
Has inotropic effect

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the actions of endothelin-1 except? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bronchodilation

 

Explanation

 

Contrary to bronchodilation, ET-1 actually causes bronchoconstriction in the lungs, mediated through ET-B receptors. This makes it detrimental in respiratory pathologies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vasoconstriction: Correct and a well-documented action of ET-1.

 

Option C. Decreased GFR: Correct, as ET-1 affects renal blood flow and filtration.

 

Option D. Has inotropic effect: Correct, ET-1 increases the force of heart contractions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Actions of Endothelin-1 (ET-1)

 

  1. On blood vessels - Potent vasoconstrictor, vascular growth, matrix production inflammation → can lead to atherosclerosis, Pulmonary artery hypertension, systemic hypertension
  2. On heart – Inotropic effect, Apoptosis, cardiomyocytes and cardio fibroblast growth and metabolism → can lead to heart failure, cardiac fibrosis, cardiac hypertrophy
  3. In the kidneys - involved in Tubuloglomerular feedback - \ GFR leads to diuresis, natriuresis, glomerular filtration, renal blood flow. Maybe be involved in glomerulosclerosis diabetic nephropathy, polycystic kidney disease, proteinuric diseases, hypertension.
  4. In the lungs, it causes bronchoconstriction (mediated via ET-B receptors)
  5. In the brain, - regulate the transport of substances across blood brain barrier (BBB).
  6. In GIT, they are involved in the migration of myenteric plexus to distal colon (failure leads to Hirschsprung's/megacolon).
  7. Platelet activation
  8. Closure of ductus arteriosus.
  9. Deletion of both alleles of ET-1 gene - craniofacial abnormalities and respiratory failure at birth.

questions.text: During rounds, your senior was discussing the given image. The following is an image of which of the following investigations? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. CT scan

 

Explanation:  

 

The above given image is a CT scan image since the bone can be identified as a high-density structure which appears white.

 

CT scan is an imaging modality which uses X-rays for cross sectional images of the body and the density of the tissue through which this x-ray beam passes is measured from the calculation of attenuation coefficient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contrast Dye study: While contrast may be used in CT scans, the term "contrast dye study" alone does not specifically indicate a CT scan.

 

Option B. X-ray: Typically provides two-dimensional imaging and lacks the cross-sectional detail shown in these images.

 

Option C. D Angiography: Focuses on blood vessels using contrast material and typically does not provide detailed images of other anatomical structures as seen in these scans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT scans are invaluable in medical imaging for providing detailed cross-sectional views of internal structures, utilizing X-ray technology to distinguish between different tissue densities, evident from the white appearance of bone and detailed soft tissue visualization in the images.

questions.text: During neonatal resuscitation of a term baby, what is the amount of oxygen you will start with? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 21%


During neonatal resuscitation, the initial amount of oxygen administered to a term baby is 21%, which corresponds to the concentration of oxygen in room air. The rationale behind starting with 21% oxygen is to avoid the potential risks associated with high concentrations of oxygen, such as oxidative stress and damage to the delicate tissues of a newborn, particularly the lungs and eyes.

 

Bag and mask ventilation using an AMBU (Artificial Manual Breathing Unit) bag, also known as a self-inflating bag, is the standard method used during neonatal resuscitation. The oxygen concentration delivered can vary depending on the setup:

 

  • AMBU without reservoir and without oxygen inlet: Provides 21% oxygen, as it uses room air.
  • AMBU with a reservoir and with oxygen inlet: Can deliver close to 100% oxygen.
  • AMBU with a reservoir but without an oxygen inlet: Delivers approximately 40% oxygen.

 

Given the guidelines and the need to balance adequate oxygenation with minimizing the risks of hyperoxia, resuscitation of a term newborn typically begins with 21% oxygen, with adjustments made based on the infant’s response and ongoing clinical assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 50%: Starting with 50% oxygen is not standard practice for neonatal resuscitation, as the recommendation is to start with room air (21%) and adjust as necessary.

 

Option C. 100%: High concentrations of oxygen, such as 100%, are avoided initially due to the risks of oxygen toxicity and oxidative stress, which can cause harm to the newborn, particularly to the eyes (risk of retinopathy of prematurity) and lungs.

 

Option D. 75%: Similar to 50% and 100%, 75% oxygen is not recommended as the starting concentration for neonatal resuscitation in term babies.

 

Educational Objective:


During neonatal resuscitation of a term baby, resuscitation should start with 21% oxygen, equivalent to room air, to minimize the risk of oxygen toxicity.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient with a midline neck swelling and histopathological findings of Orphan Annie eye nuclei on biopsy as shown below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Papillary carcinoma

 

The presence of empty appearing nuclei (Orphan Annie eye nuclei) is diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

 

  • Histological Appearance: Papillary carcinoma has a papillary growth pattern with branching papillae composed of fibrovascular stalks and cuboidal epithelial cells.
  • Orphan Annie Eye Nuclei: Papillary carcinoma cells have distinct Orphan Annie eye nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin and an optically clear or empty appearance.
  • Psammoma Bodies: Papillary carcinoma often contains psammoma bodies, which are concentrically calcified structures found within the papillae.
  • Lymphatic Invasion: Papillary carcinoma commonly exhibits lymphatic invasion; involvement of blood vessels is uncommon.
  • Genetic Alterations: Papillary carcinoma is associated with specific genetic changes, including gene rearrangements like RET/PTC and NTRK1, as well as BRAF gene mutations.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Follicular carcinoma: This is incorrect. Follicular carcinoma typically presents with a different histological pattern, characterized by small follicles. It does not exhibit Orphan Annie eye nuclei, which are specific to papillary carcinoma.

 

Option C. Toxic nodular goitre: This is incorrect. Toxic nodular goitre, or multinodular goitre, is a benign condition and does not present with Orphan Annie eye nuclei or the other specific histological features of papillary carcinoma.

 

Option D. Medullary carcinoma: This is incorrect. Medullary carcinoma arises from parafollicular C cells and is characterized by amyloid deposits and the presence of calcitonin, rather than the histological features such as Orphan Annie eye nuclei seen in papillary carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Orphan Annie eye nuclei on histopathological examination is a key diagnostic feature of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

questions.text: Which structure develops from the 6th pharyngeal arch artery on the left side? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ductus arteriosus

 

The 6th pharyngeal arch artery plays a crucial role in embryonic development, particularly in forming structures related to the circulatory system. On the left side, the distal part of the 6th pharyngeal arch artery develops into the ductus arteriosus, a vital fetal blood vessel that allows blood to bypass the lungs, which are not yet functional before birth. After birth, the ductus arteriosus normally closes and becomes the ligamentum arteriosum.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arch of aorta: The arch of the aorta is primarily derived from the left 4th pharyngeal arch artery, not the 6th.

 

Option C. Subclavian artery: The right subclavian artery is derived from the right 4th pharyngeal arch artery and other structures, while the left subclavian artery arises from the left 7th intersegmental artery.

 

Option D. Common carotid artery: The common carotid artery primarily arises from the 3rd pharyngeal arch artery, not the 6th.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ductus arteriosus, a critical structure in fetal circulation, develops from the distal part of the 6th pharyngeal arch artery on the left side.

questions.text: The given image is the logo for which of the following health programs? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) National Leprosy Eradication Program


The logo shown is for the National Leprosy Eradication Program (NLEP). The design of the logo holds significant meaning:

 

  • Sun: The sun in the center of the hand symbolizes hope and optimism, reflecting the positive outcomes of leprosy treatment.
  • Lotus Flower: This represents purity and beauty, indicating that there should be no stigma attached to those affected by leprosy.
  • Cured Thumb: The image of the healed thumb symbolizes that leprosy is a 100% curable disease. The thumb indicates that the affected person has been cured and is now a fully integrated member of society.
  • House-Shaped Hand: The hand shaped like a house emphasizes that the cured individual is an integral part of their family and community.

 

These elements collectively reinforce the message of hope, inclusion, and the need to remove stigma associated with leprosy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Integrated Disease Surveillance Program (logo):

 

 

Option B.  National TB Elimination Program (logo):

 

 

Option D.  National Health Mission (logo):

 

 

Educational Objective:


The National Leprosy Eradication Program logo symbolizes hope, the curability of leprosy, and the inclusion of cured individuals into society, promoting a stigma-free approach towards the disease.

questions.text: A child in your unit is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). According to the WHO criteria, SAM is defined best by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Weight for height less than -3SD

 

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is best defined as weight for height less than median minus -3SD

 

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by the WHO as any of the following:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weight for age less than -2SD: This defines moderate acute malnutrition (MAM), not severe acute malnutrition (SAM).

 

Option B. Weight for height less than +2SD: This would indicate overnutrition or obesity, not malnutrition.

 

Option C. Weight for age less than +3SD: This is not relevant to malnutrition and could indicate overnutrition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is defined by the WHO as weight-for-height (or length) below -3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards, presence of bilateral pitting edema, or mid-upper arm circumference less than 11.5 cm.

questions.text: Most important enzyme in acute inflammation during respiratory burst is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) NADPH oxidase

 

The respiratory burst is a crucial process in the immune response where neutrophils rapidly increase their oxygen consumption to generate reactive oxygen species (ROS) to kill invading pathogens. The key enzyme that initiates this process is NADPH oxidase (aka Respiratory burst oxidase enzyme). NADPH oxidase catalyzes the conversion of oxygen (O₂) into superoxide anions (O₂⁻), which are then further converted into more reactive species like hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) and hypochlorous acid (HOCl-) via other enzymes like myeloperoxidase (MPO). These reactive species are potent antimicrobial agents, essential for destroying bacteria and fungi during acute inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MPO (Myeloperoxidase): While MPO is important in the conversion of hydrogen peroxide into hypochlorous acid (a powerful microbicidal agent), it acts downstream of NADPH oxidase. Thus, it is not the primary enzyme initiating the respiratory burst.

 

Option C. Defensin: Defensins are antimicrobial peptides that kill bacteria particularly against mycobacterium tuberculosis, by disrupting their cell membranes. They do not play a direct role in the respiratory burst or the generation of ROS.

 

Option D. Catalase: Catalase is an enzyme that breaks down hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen, acting as an antioxidant to protect cells from oxidative damage. It does not contribute to the generation of ROS in the respiratory burst and is involved in mitigating the effects of ROS rather than promoting their formation.

 

Also, Catalase activity is used as a diagnostic tool to differentiate between types of bacteria. For example, the presence of catalase is used to distinguish catalase-positive organisms like Staphylococcus (staph) from catalase-negative organisms like Streptococcus (strep).

 

Educational Objective:

 

NADPH oxidase is the most important enzyme in the process of respiratory burst during acute inflammation. It initiates the production of reactive oxygen species, which are crucial for the immune system's ability to kill pathogens.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a 2-month history of persistent diarrhea, a worsening rash on his hands and neck, and episodes of memory lapses and confusion. His diet primarily consists of untreated maize (corn). Which vitamin deficiency is he most likely suffering from? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Niacin

 

The patient's symptoms and dietary history suggest he is suffering from pellagra, which is caused by a deficiency in niacin (Vitamin B3). Pellagra is characterized by the "4 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and death if untreated.

 

Symptom:

 

4Ds: Dermatitis, dementia, diarrhea, and death

 

Dermatitis is seen around the neck of the person k/a Cassal’s necklace.

 

Consumption of untreated maize as a primary dietary staple is a recognized risk factor for pellagra because maize contains niacin in a form that is not bioavailable unless treated with lime or alkali (a process known as nixtamalization).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Deficiency can cause ariboflavinosis, characterized by sore throat, redness and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat, cracks or sores on the outsides of the lips (cheilosis) and at the corners of the mouth (angular stomatitis), and a moist, scaly skin inflammation (seborrheic dermatitis).

 

Option C. Thiamine (Vitamin B1): Deficiency causes beriberi, which can present as dry beriberi (neuropathy and muscle weakness) or wet beriberi (cardiovascular symptoms), and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome (neurological symptoms).

 

Option D. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Deficiency can lead to microcytic anemia, dermatitis, depression, confusion, and convulsions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra, caused by niacin deficiency, presents with a triad of symptoms: dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. A diet primarily consisting of untreated maize can increase the risk of this deficiency.

choices.text: Collect water from already leaking taps
Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute
Water sample container is kept close to the tap avoid spillage
Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

questions.text: How is water collected for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

 

When collecting water for bacteriological examination, especially during a disease outbreak, it is crucial to follow proper procedures to avoid contamination and ensure the sample's accuracy. The best practice is to collect water from a gentle stream to avoid splashing, which can introduce contaminants from the environment into the sample.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collect water from already leaking tape: Not recommended as it could contaminate the sample and may lead to false results.

 

Option B. Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute: Before collecting, let water flow for at least 2 minutes

 

Option C. Water sample container is kept close to the tap to avoid spillage: It is a good practice but this practice alone does not ensure the proper collection of the sample.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When collecting water for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak, it is crucial to collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing and potential contamination. This practice ensures the accuracy and reliability of the water sample.

questions.text: A patient comes to the casualty with organophosphate poisoning. He was started on atropine infusion and pralidoxime. After 2 hours, the patient had a sudden rise in temperature. What is the likely cause of fever? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atropine toxicity

 

The most likely cause of fever in this patient is atropine toxicity.

 

The clinical scenario is of organophosphate poisoning and patient was started on atropine infusion and pralidoxime.

 

Atropine is a non-specific muscarinic receptor blocker, but not the nicotinic effects.

 

A/E of Atropine include –

 

  • ↑body temperature (due to ↓sweating)
  • ↑ HR
  • Dry mouth, Dry & flushed skin
  • Cycloplegia
  • Constipation
  • Disorientation
  • Can cause acute angle-closure glaucoma in older adults (due to mydriasis)
  • Urinary retention in men with prostatic hyperplasia
  • Hyperthermia in infants

 

Pralidoxime is given as an adjuvant to atropine in cases of organophosphate poisoning. It does not increase body temperature.

 

Hence, the sudden rise in body temperature is most likely attributed to Atropine Toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Side effect of pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is used as an adjuvant in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning to reactivate acetylcholinesterase. It does not typically cause hyperthermia or significantly affect body temperature.

 

Option C. Due to organophosphate poisoning: Organophosphate poisoning typically causes symptoms due to excessive acetylcholine, such as sweating, salivation, bronchorrhea, bradycardia, and muscle fasciculations. It does not typically cause a sudden rise in temperature as described in this scenario.

 

Option D. Idiopathic: An idiopathic cause is one that arises spontaneously or for which the cause is unknown. Given the context of the medication administration and known side effects, the fever is more likely due to atropine toxicity rather than an unexplained cause.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which among the following is the most specific disease caused by Streptococcus agalactiae?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neonatal sepsis

 

Streptococcus agalactiae, also known as Group B Streptococcus (GBS), is a significant cause of neonatal infections. It is the leading cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis globally. The bacteria exhibit beta-hemolysis on blood agar, characterized by complete lysis of red blood cells around the colonies, forming a clear zone. This hemolytic property helps in identifying and differentiating it from other types of Streptococci. GBS is biochemically identified as hippurate hydrolysis positive and CAMP test positive, both of which are unique to this bacterium. These tests confirm its identity and help in diagnosing infections caused by it.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Infective endocarditis: Although Streptococcus agalactiae can occasionally cause infective endocarditis, it is not the most specific or common disease caused by this bacterium. Infective endocarditis is more commonly associated with other Streptococcus species, such as Streptococcus viridans.

 

Option C. Dental caries: Dental caries are typically associated with Streptococcus mutans, not Streptococcus agalactiae. S. mutans plays a primary role in the development of tooth decay due to its ability to ferment sugars into acids, which demineralize the dental enamel.

 

Option D. Pharyngitis with or without tonsillitis: Pharyngitis, commonly known as strep throat, is primarily caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), not Streptococcus agalactiae. S. pyogenes is known for causing various suppurative and non-suppurative infections, including pharyngitis, rheumatic fever, and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus) is the most common cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis.

questions.text: The observed myocardial stunning pattern does not match the ECG findings of a patient. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

 

 

Stress cardiomyopathy commonly affects Women (post-menopausal) > men predominantly due to emotional > physical stress. Neurogenic myocardial stunning occurs leading to heart failure.

 

Beta-2 (Gs stimulation) is present at base and b2 (Gi) activation leads to hypercontractility at the base & apical ballooning giving a typical Takotsubo appearance.

 

ECG mimics ACS, RWMA not corresponding to single artery territory, normal CAG with Mild troponin elevation are clues to takotsubo.

 

Treatment with beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors if non-responsive. Carries good prognosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option B: Restrictive cardiomyopathy causes diastolic dysfunction on but NOT significant ECG changes.

 

Option C: Brugada syndrome is a channelopathy caused due LOF (loss of function) mutation of cardiac SCN5a (Sodium channel) resulting in transmural voltage difference between endocardium-epicardium causing ventricular arrhythmias which initially affects the RV myocardium.

 

 

Option D: Tamponade occurs due to rapid accumulation of fluid/blood in the pericardium producing the characteristic Beck triad (↑JVP ↓ Heart sounds ↓ BP).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy should be considered when a patient's clinical presentation includes myocardial stunning that does not correspond to ECG findings typical of a myocardial infarction, especially in the context of recent significant emotional or physical stress.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/Cardiomyopathies/Chap 259

questions.text:
A pediatrician is reviewing mortality trends among children aged between 1-4 years based on verbal autopsy reports from the years 2010-2013. She wants to educate parents on the primary causes of death to improve preventive measures in her community. From the list provided below, which sequence correctly represents the leading causes of death in a descending order for this age group? [INICET MAY 2021]

 

  1. Diarrhea
  2. Pneumonia
  3. Malaria
  4. Injuries
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 2>1>4>3

 

  • According to the verbal autopsy report of 2010-2013, leading cause of death among 1–4-year-old children in a developing country like India in descending order is Pneumonia > Diarrhea > Injuries > Malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 In a developed country, leading causes of death are:

 

  1. Accident injury
  2. Congenital anomaly
  3. Neoplasms
  4. Influenza
  5. Pneumonia

questions.text: Which of the following is the best level of prevention of breast cancer? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Early diagnosis and treatment

 

Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial in the management of breast cancer. This involves screening methods such as mammography, which can detect cancer at an early stage when it is more likely to be treated successfully. Early treatment can significantly improve survival rates and outcomes for patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Specific protection: Specific protection involves preventive measures that protect against specific diseases, such as vaccinations or using protective equipment. Currently, there is no vaccine or specific protective measure that can prevent breast cancer.

 

Option C. Disability limitation: Disability limitation is part of tertiary prevention and focuses on minimizing the impact of an ongoing illness that has already caused some level of disability. It involves strategies to prevent complications and further disability. This is more applicable after a disease has been diagnosed and is not the best level of prevention for breast cancer.

 

Option D. Rehabilitation: Rehabilitation is also a part of tertiary prevention and aims to help individuals recover as much function as possible after a disease has caused disability. It includes therapies to restore physical, psychological, and social functioning. While important, it is not the best preventive strategy for breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early diagnosis and treatment (secondary prevention) are the most effective methods for preventing the progression of breast cancer, as they allow for early detection and intervention, significantly improving the chances of successful treatment and reducing mortality rates.

questions.text: Varicella-zoster virus remains dormant in the: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dorsal root ganglion

 

  • Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution as shown in the image below.

 

 

 

  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear.
  • The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  • Painful zoster infections in adults
  • Facial zoster at any age
  • Immunocompromised
  • The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ventral root

  • It is not associated with the latency of VZV.
  • The ventral root carries motor neurons, not sensory neurons, and VZV is not known to remain dormant in motor neurons or their associated structures.

 

Option B. Skin

  • It is not a site of viral latency.
  • While VZV does cause lesions in the skin, it does not remain dormant there.
  • Skin lesions occur during active infection when the virus reactivates and travels down sensory nerves to the skin.

 

Option C. Medulla oblongata

  • It is a part of the brainstem and is not associated with the latency of VZV.
  • This virus specifically becomes dormant in the peripheral nervous system, not within the central nervous system structures such as the medulla oblongata.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dorsal root ganglion is the site of latency for the Varicella-zoster virus, which is important for understanding the pathogenesis of both primary varicella infection and reactivation as herpes zoster.

 

Reference

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 25.27-25.28

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 4.13

Question Level – EASY

Question Id-7448 Unique Key-Q4313194

questions.text: Effacement of podocyte foot processes is seen in which of the following diseases? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Minimal change disease

 

Effacement of the podocyte foot processes is characteristically seen in minimal change disease (MCD), which is also called lipoid nephrosis.

 

On light microscopy, characteristic feature is no apparent abnormality in the glomeruli except for slight increase in the mesangial matrix at the most.

 

 

By electron microscopy, the most characteristic feature of the disease is identified which is diffuse flattening of foot processes of the visceral epithelial cells (podocytes) and, hence, the name foot process disease or podocytopathy.

 

In contrast to other types of GN, no deposits are visible, and the GBM is normal. No complement or immunoglobulin deposits are detected using immunofluorescence microscopy (nil deposit disease).

 

It's also seen in other diseases like membranous nephropathy and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. These diseases are also known as podocytopathies because they affect podocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Steroid resistant glomerulonephritis: This term is more of a clinical description rather than a specific pathological diagnosis. Steroid-resistant cases can include various glomerulonephritis types such as focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), which also shows podocyte effacement but is not the classic example of it.

 

Option C. Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN): RPGN is characterized by crescent formation in the glomeruli and is associated with severe glomerular damage and rapid loss of kidney function. It does not specifically show effacement of podocyte foot processes as its primary feature.

 

Option D. Chronic glomerulonephritis: Chronic glomerulonephritis encompasses various forms of long-standing glomerular diseases leading to chronic kidney damage. It is associated with glomerular sclerosis and interstitial fibrosis but not specifically with podocyte foot process effacement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Effacement of podocyte foot processes is the characteristic feature of minimal change disease (MCD), which presents with nephrotic syndrome and shows normal glomeruli on light microscopy but diffuse foot process flattening on electron microscopy.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver in image below. (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pringle's maneuver

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts a surgical procedure known as Pringle's maneuver, which involves inserting a finger from the greater sac to the lesser sac through the epiploic foramen (also known as the foramen of Winslow). The epiploic foramen is the communication between the greater and lesser sacs, and its boundaries are of great importance.

During hepatobiliary surgery, there is a risk of rupturing the vein, artery, and duct (VAD) located along the free margin of the lesser omentum. To prevent leakage from these structures, the surgeon can either clamp them along the free margin or insert a finger behind the lesser omentum and place the thumb above it, compressing the VAD between the finger and thumb. This surgical procedure is known as Pringle's maneuver.

 

 

The maneuver involves inserting the finger in front of the stomach (greater sac) and passing it behind the stomach (lesser sac) through the epiploic foramen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mattox maneuver: Incorrect. The Mattox maneuver is a surgical technique used to control bleeding from the inferior vena cava or hepatic veins during liver trauma. It involves a thoracoabdominal approach and manual compression of the bleeding site.

 

Option C. Cattell-Braash maneuver: Incorrect. The Cattell-Braash maneuver is a surgical technique used to expose the retroperitoneal structures, such as the aorta, inferior vena cava, and kidneys, by mobilizing the colon and small bowel to the right side of the abdomen.

 

Option D. Liver hanging maneuver: Incorrect. The liver hanging maneuver is a technique used during liver resection to facilitate the transection of the liver parenchyma. It involves passing a tape or a catheter between the liver and the inferior vena cava to provide traction and guidance during the resection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pringle's maneuver is a surgical procedure used to control bleeding during hepatobiliary surgery by compressing the vein, artery, and duct (VAD) along the free margin of the lesser omentum through the epiploic foramen.

questions.text:
What diseases' risk is elevated due to smoking? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Duct ectasia
  2. Fibroadenoma
  3. Mondor's disease
  4. Breast carcinoma
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

 

Cigarette smoking elevates the likelihood of experiencing duct ectasia, Mondor's disease, and breast carcinoma.

 

1. Duct ectasia: Typically seen in smokers. Patient presents with greenish Nipple discharge and Lump in breast with nipple retraction. Management is done by Conical excision of ductal system - Hadfield procedure.

 

3. Mondor's disease: Superficial thrombophlebitis of veins of breast / chest wall or axilla – males. Patient presents with cord like, thick, tender initially. Most common vein involves lateral thoracic vein. Smoking was identified as a possible contributing element in the development of Mondor's disease.

 

4. Breast carcinoma: Risk factors involve Age > 60, Early menarche (< 12 years), late menopause (>55 years), nulli-parity, late age of first child birth, Hormone replacement therapy, Inadequate breast feeding (breast feeding for > 12 months reduces risk), Alcohol & smoking consumption, obesity, Prior chest wall radiation, Family history.

 

Other Option:

 

2. Fibroadenoma: Tumor of breast arising from ductal epithelium or fibrous elements or both. It has two components – fibrous or stromal elements + glandular elements. Patient presents with slow growing lump (2-3cm), mobile like a mouse in breast. Smoking is not a risk factor for fibroadenomas.

questions.text: A patient presents with an BT leprosy lesion on the face as shown in the image below. Which of the following nerves is most commonly involved in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Facial Nerve

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests a case of leprosy, with the facial nerve being the most commonly affected cranial nerve.

 

  • Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which impacts the mucous membranes, cutaneous tissues, and peripheral nerves leading to sensory and motor deficits.

 

Most commonly affected nerves:

 

  • Peripheral nerves: Ulnar > Posterior tibial nerve, median, and lateral popliteal nerves.
  • Cranial nerves: Facial nerve > Trigeminal nerve.
  • Notably, facial skin lesions are associated with a 10-fold increase in the risk of facial nerve involvement in leprosy cases.
  • Facial nerve involvement can lead to facial muscle weakness, paralysis, and loss of facial expressions, which are characteristic features of this condition.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve:

 

  • The trigeminal nerve (fifth cranial nerve) primarily innervates the face and is responsible for sensations such as touch and pain.
  • While it can be affected in leprosy, it is not the most commonly involved nerve in BT leprosy lesions on the face.

 

Option C. Abducens nerve:

 

  • The abducens nerve (sixth cranial nerve) controls the movement of the lateral rectus muscle of the eye.
  • In leprosy, it is less commonly involved compared to the facial nerve, especially in BT leprosy.

 

Option D. Optic nerve:

 

The optic nerve (second cranial nerve) is responsible for vision and is not commonly affected in leprosy lesions on the face.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients presenting with leprosy lesions on the face, the most commonly involved nerve is the facial nerve (option A).

 

References:

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 28, Page no 28.1, 28.3, 28.12

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1385, 1386, 1388

questions.text: A pregnant woman was prescribed indomethacin. Which of the following effects does the drug have on the fetus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Premature closure of ductus arteriosus

 

Indomethacin is an NSAID, that acts by inhibiting the Cyclooxygenase (COX) enzyme, thereby decreasing the synthesis of Prostaglandins. Prostaglandins are necessary for maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus in the fetus. Therefore, Indomethacin if given to a pregnant woman can lead to premature closure of the ductus arteriosus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Keeps ductus arteriosus patent: Indomethacin does not keep the ductus arteriosus patent; instead, it promotes its closure by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis.

 

Option C. Closure of fossa ovalis: The closure of the fossa ovalis is not influenced by indomethacin. The fossa ovalis is a different fetal structure that closes postnatally due to changes in pressure gradients.

 

Option D. Premature closure of ductus venous: The ductus venosus closure is not affected by indomethacin. This structure typically closes naturally after birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indomethacin, an NSAID, can cause the premature closure of the ductus arteriosus in a fetus due to its inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis. Therefore, caution should be exercised when prescribing this drug to pregnant women, particularly in the third trimester.

questions.text: Which Reflex is responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bainbridge reflex

 

Explanation

 

Bainbridge reflex is a cardioaccelerator reflex that increases the heart rate when venous return is increased. Since this reflex arises from right atrium, it is also called right atrial reflex.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. J Reflex: Apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension due to J receptor (C-receptor, juxta-pulmonary capillary receptor) stimulation.

 

Option B. Cushing Reflex: Incorrect because the Cushing reflex involves increased blood pressure, bradycardia, and respiratory depression in response to increased intracranial pressure, not right atrial distension.

 

Option C. Bezold-Jarisch Reflex: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is the reflex characterized by bradycardia and hypotension, caused by stimulation of chemoreceptors present in the wall of left ventricles by substances such as alkaloids. It is also called coronary chemoreflex. Vagal fibers form the afferent and efferent pathways of this reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bainbridge reflex is responsible for inducing tachycardia in response to right atrial distension. It serves to adjust heart rate upward when venous return to the heart increases, ensuring optimal cardiac output and circulation efficiency.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic SDH

 

Chronic Subdural Hematoma (SDH) is characterized by a hypodense (dark) appearance on CT scans due to the older age of the blood collection, which becomes less dense over time. The hallmark shape of a subdural hematoma is crescent-shaped or moon-like, indicating that the bleed is located between the dura mater and the arachnoid membrane, spreading widely along the brain’s surface.

 

In this image:

 

  • The hypodense (dark) appearance confirms that the bleed is chronic.
  • The crescent shape seen in the scan is typical for a subdural hematoma (SDH).

 

These findings are classic for a chronic SDH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute EDH (Epidural Hematoma): Acute EDH appears as a biconvex (lens-shaped) collection that is hyperdense (bright) on imaging due to fresh bleeding. It is not crescent-shaped and does not appear hypodense as seen in this image.

 

Option B. Chronic EDH: Chronic EDH is rare and still appears biconvex, like acute EDH. The imaging features shown here do not match EDH patterns.

 

Option D. Acute SDH: Acute SDH appears hyperdense (bright) because the blood is fresh and denser. It is crescent-shaped but does not match the hypodense characteristics of a chronic bleed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A crescent or moon-shaped, hypodense (dark) collection on a CT scan suggests a chronic subdural hematoma (SDH).

questions.text: While administering epidural anesthesia, which structure is not punctured before injecting the drug?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Arachnoid mater

 

Explanation:

 

During epidural anesthesia, the anesthetic agent is injected into the epidural space, which lies outside the dura mater. The needle passes through several layers of tissue but does not puncture the dura mater, arachnoid mater, or enter the subarachnoid space.

The layers that are punctured during epidural anesthesia, in order, are:

 

  1. Skin
  2. Superficial fascia
  3. Supraspinous ligament
  4. Interspinous ligament
  5. Ligamentum flavum

 

After passing through the ligamentum flavum, the needle enters the epidural space, where the anesthetic agent is deposited.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supraspinous ligament : This ligament is punctured during epidural anesthesia.

 

Option B. Interspinous ligament : This ligament is also punctured during the procedure.

 

Option C. Ligamentum flavum : The needle passes through the ligamentum flavum to reach the epidural space.

 

Note: that this procedure differs from a lumbar puncture, where the needle passes through the dura mater, arachnoid mater, and enters the subarachnoid space (represented by the mnemonic "DAS": Dura mater, Arachnoid mater, Subarachnoid space).

 

Educational Objective:

 

During epidural anesthesia, the arachnoid mater is not punctured. The anesthetic agent is injected into the epidural space, which lies outside the dura mater, after passing through the skin, superficial fascia, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, and ligamentum flavum.

questions.text: Heavy metal chelators are all EXCEPT:(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oxime

 

Oximes are not typically used as heavy metal chelators. Oximes are compounds containing the functional group R1C=NOH. They are more commonly associated with the reactivation of acetylcholinesterase in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penicillamine: Penicillamine is a heavy metal chelator used in the treatment of Wilson's disease and lead poisoning.

 

Option C. BAL (British Anti-Lewisite or Dimercaprol): BAL is a heavy metal chelator used for arsenic, gold, and mercury poisoning.

 

Option D. Trientine: Trientine is a heavy metal chelator used in the treatment of Wilson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heavy metal chelators play a crucial role in the treatment of heavy metal poisoning. They work by binding to toxic heavy metals and aiding in their elimination from the body. Each heavy metal chelator may have specific indications and is used for particular heavy metal poisonings.

choices.text: Restrictive lung disease with bronchodilator reversibility
Restrictive lung disease without bronchodilator reversibility

questions.text:
A chronic cigarette smoker now joined a construction company. His pulmonary function test results are given below.(INICET MAY 2023)

 

Initial lung volumes were: FEV1 - 0.9L, FVC - 1.9L, FEV1/FVC - 0.4

 

After bronchodilation: FEV1 - 1.9L, FVC - 3.9L, FEV1/FVC - 0.4

 

What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Obstructive disease with bronchodilator reversibility

 

The pulmonary function test results show a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio, consistent with obstructive lung disease. Significant improvement in FEV1 post-bronchodilation indicates reversibility (FEV1 - anything >200ml is significant), suggesting conditions like asthma or COPD with reversible obstruction.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Vascular disease with bronchodilator reversibility: Pulmonary function tests do not suggest vascular disease.


Option B. Restrictive lung disease with bronchodilator reversibility: Restrictive diseases show reduced volumes but normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio.


Option C. Restrictive lung disease without bronchodilator reversibility: Not applicable as the patient shows obstructive pattern with reversibility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obstructive lung diseases, such as asthma or COPD, may show bronchodilator reversibility.
